**Case Summary: Anubhav Jain vs. Satish Kumar Jain & Anr. (2023/DHC/000233)**

**Background:**
The case involves a petition filed by Anubhav Jain, a Director of M/s. Jain Shikanji Private Limited (JSPL), under Sections 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999. The petition seeks to cancel a registered device mark (Certificate No. 2772286) granted to Respondent 1, Satish Kumar Jain, on June 18, 2021. Additionally, the petitioner seeks rectification of the register of trademarks by removing the said registered trademark of Respondent 1.

**Legal Issues:**
The primary issue in this case is the maintainability of the petition, which was raised by Respondent 1 as a preliminary objection. The objection is based on Section 124 of the Trademarks Act, 1999. The court needs to determine whether the petition is maintainable and whether the registrar or the High Court has jurisdiction to hear the matter.

**Arguments:**
The petitioner's counsel, Ms. Kangan Roda, argued in favor of the maintainability of the petition. On the other hand, Respondent 1's counsel, Mr. Gaurav Barathi, raised the preliminary objection, citing Section 124 of the Trademarks Act.

**Court Findings:**
After hearing the arguments, the Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar directed that the preliminary objection be taken up and decided first. The court noted that Respondent 1 had filed a suit (CS (Comm) 171/2021) against the petitioner in September 2021, which may be relevant to the maintainability of the present petition.

**Decision:**
The court decided to hear and decide the preliminary objection first, as directed on September 23, 2022. The decision on the maintainability of the petition would determine the course of the proceedings. Unfortunately, the provided document does not contain the final decision on the preliminary objection or the outcome of the case.

**Key Sections of the Trademarks Act, 1999:**

* Section 57: Power to cancel or vary registration and to rectify the register.
* Section 124: Not explicitly mentioned in the provided document, but it is likely related to the jurisdiction of the court or the registrar in trademark matters.
* Section 125: Application for rectification of register to be made to High Court in certain cases.

The case highlights the complexities of trademark law and the importance of procedural compliance in intellectual property disputes. The court's decision on the preliminary objection will be crucial in determining the outcome of the case.

As per the PDF document "Anubhav Jain v. Satish Kumar Jain & Anr." (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000233, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 55/2021), the legal arguments revolve around Section 124 of the Trademarks Act. The section applies when a defendant raises a plea of invalidity of the plaintiff's trademark in a suit, and no rectification proceedings are pending. The Trial Court must then raise an issue regarding the validity of the trademark and adjourn the case for three months to enable the defendant to apply for rectification.

In this case, the petitioner (Anubhav Jain) did not raise a plea of invalidity of Respondent 1's (Satish Kumar Jain) trademark in their written statement. Therefore, Section 124 does not apply. Moreover, the petitioner has an independent right to invoke Section 57 of the Trademarks Act, seeking rectification of the register and cancellation of Respondent 1's trademark.

The judgment of the Supreme Court in Patel Field Marshal Agencies v. P.M. Diesels Ltd. is cited, which clarifies the provisions of Section 111 of the 1958 Act regarding the stay of proceedings where the validity of registration of the trademark is questioned. The court's decision is based on the facts of the case and the applicable laws. tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Anubhav Jain v. Satish Kumar Jain & Anr." (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000233, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 55/2021), the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi made a decision on a petition filed by Anubhav Jain against Satish Kumar Jain and another respondent. The petitioner was represented by Ms. Kangan Roda and Mr. Nitesh Jain, while the respondents were represented by Mr. Gaurav Barathi, Ms. Muskan Arora, and Mr. Vishal Shrivastava.

The court rejected the preliminary objection raised by Mr. Barathi, which stated that the petition was not maintainable because the petitioner ought to have obtained leave from the trial court before instituting the petition. The court held that the right to seek cancellation of a mark and rectification of the register under Section 57 and Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act are independent rights available to an interested party.

The court also clarified that the judgment in Patel Field Marshal Agencies did not hold that the right available under Section 57 stood eviscerated. The court stated that there is no clause in Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act that makes it subject to any other provision in the Act, and no non-obstante clause in Section 124 that gives it pre-eminence over other provisions.

The court granted two weeks' time to the petitioner to place the rejoinder to the reply filed by the respondents on record and re-notified the case for disposal on February 8, 2023. The decision was made by Justice C. Hari Shankar on January 9, 2023, as stated in the PDF document.
